awd_abstract_narration:
The Faculty Workload and Rewards Project aims to study and transform workplace structures and cultures that result in inequality between science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) men and women faculty in campus service, teaching, and mentoring workloads.  The project will test whether departments that undergo a three-year intervention to address workload inequality show improvements in STEM women faculty members' sense of procedural and distributive justice, retention, satisfaction, organizational commitment, and satisfaction with time spent on teaching and service versus research.  The project will also measure changes in organizational practices that result from the interventions such as dashboards and new workload and reward system policies.  The outcomes of this project will have broad potential impact for other public state institutions, which are critical to improving the number of women and underrepresented racial and ethnic minority students in STEM fields.  The project will create a repository of dashboard templates that can be used by other departments, colleges, and institutions to assess micro-equities in workload and establish department-based organizational practices that make campus service, teaching, and mentoring workloads fairer and more transparent.  The study has the potential to make long-term shifts possible through structural change in workload assignments and accountability, and cultural changes in transparency and bias regarding those assignments.  

The study includes a randomized trial of forty-two STEM and Social Science academic departments from Maryland, North Carolina, and Massachusetts.  Twenty-one departments will act as controls and twenty-one departments will be experimental departments that will engage in four workload interventions over three years.  These interventions include: (1) the creation of workload dashboards to enhance transparency; (2) workload and reward system adjustments to remedy inequitable workloads by gender, race, and career stage; (3) individual career training and peer support for management of workload; and (4) department-wide faculty training on how unconscious bias and department organizational practices can affect workloads and harm careers.  The design allows systematic diagnosis and measurement of workload and gender and race inequality in new ways in a range of diverse departments and institutions.  By engaging a stratified random assignment design and collecting both climate and workload data from each control and experimental department, the project will measure both changes in faculty perceptions of workload fairness (procedural justice) and actual workload, policies and rewards (distributive justice).  This project takes an important issue and studies it systematically, with a large sample, using multiple methods and clear focus.  This approach is a rigorous design for the study of faculty workload and rewards and offers an approach that can be replicated in future studies.  

The NSF ADVANCE Partnerships for Learning and Adaptation Networks (PLAN) program track supports projects that promote the adaptation and implementation of previously effective ADVANCE programs in new contexts and the testing of innovative strategies to promote the participation, success, and advancement of women in STEM academic careers.  PLAN projects also contribute to the knowledge base on gender equity in STEM academic careers.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The ways in which faculty work is taken up, assigned and rewarded within many departments is unequal. Women and Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) faculty members tend to do more teaching, advising/mentoring, and service and spend less time on research. For colleges and universities to fulfill their missions and goals, it is critical that activities that occur within each of these domains are completed. However, each domain is not considered equally within traditional faculty reward systems. In many universities, research continues to be more heavily valued compared to teaching and service, and faculty members who spend more time on teaching and service encounter longer times to promotion or no promotion at all. Thus, the unequal distribution of faculty labor contributes to a less diverse and less equitable academic workplace.

 

The purpose of the Faculty Workload and Rewards Project was to address this problem and to enhance equity in the way faculty workload is taken up, assigned, and rewarded. We took an action-research approach, working with 53 academic departments and small colleges in 20 public higher education institutions to actively understand workload inequality within their local contexts and put in place policies and practices that ameliorated inequality. We designed the project as an experiment, comparing departments that participated in the project activities to those that did not, to understand the impact of the intervention we created over time.

 

The workload intervention consisted of four activities. First, departments participated in an evidence-based workshop that reviewed the social science on how faculty workload arises and why it is a problem for diversity, equity, and inclusion and departmental effectiveness. Second, departments created a work activity dashboard, wherein they collected faculty work data in areas not commonly counted in extant reward systems (e.g., number of student advisees, number of committees service). The dashboards aggregated the data by rank, appointment type, gender, and race (as relevant). Next, based on the dashboard, departments diagnosed specific kinds of workload inequalities manifesting in their unit and identified salient policies and practices that might address the problem(s). Finally, department members participated in individual professional development related to aligning work time with work priorities.

 

Our project revealed several novel results that contribute to academic policy and practice:

  • There are six departmental conditions associated with workload equity: Transparency, clarity, credit, norms, context, and accountability. Faculty members in departments with some or all of these conditions present are more satisfied with their workloads and feel like their department’s approach to workload is more equitable.
  • Certain policies and practices can foster these six conditions. For instance, making faculty workload data available through a dashboard fosters transparency. Writing down faculty expectations in the domains of teaching, research, and service enhances clarity. Creating systems wherein faculty members receive teaching or service releases for previously unrecognized labor creates credit. Rotating high intensity service roles can enhance norms. Individualized workload agreements and modified pathways to tenure and promotion recognize context. Auditing committee service and clarifying committee roles creates more accountability.
  • The intervention was effective in spurring the uptake of these policies and practice and enhanced workload equity within the departments in the project. Faculty members in departments that participated in the intervention were more likely to report their department’s approach to workload distribution was fair and more likely to report that they could advocate for workload equity reform within their units.

 

A final goal of the Faculty Workload and Rewards Project was to disseminate lessons learned to communities of practice, including provosts, faculty affairs and faculty development professionals, higher education researchers, diversity, equity, and inclusion officers, deans, and department chairs. We have disseminated peer-reviewed results in scientific, sociological, and higher education journals. We have also published op-eds and created Sci-Ani videos to share our results with a wider audience. Finally, we partnered with the American Council on Education to create a report and a workshop on our project. Project PIs and Co-PIs have also been asked to share their insights with colleges and university across the United States and abroad.

 

In conclusion, the Faculty Workload and Rewards Project offers a model that academic units can use to understand faculty workload inequality; diagnose its causes; and make concrete changes to policy and practice, with the overall goal of making the academic workplace a more just and equitable environment for all faculty.
